transcripts.text: It was rough for a while, but I got through it.
And you're stronger.
These tears are not showing strength, but also tears aren't weakness either.
Your mascara isn't running.
Thank God.  I was so worried about that.
I'm loving your blues.  The two of you are so well coordinated.
Look at this, the blue here.
We tried a little bit.  We did.  Just for you guys.
I had so much shakiness in my identity growing up that by the time I was able to come out, it felt like...
Oh.  Was there acceptance?

At first, no.  I think there was a little bit of denial on everyone's part, especially because I'm bisexual, so I was dating men still at the same time.  So they were like, oh, she'll still end up with a man.  It'll be fine.

I always had that feeling of just being, you know, sort of like a second-class citizen in my own family.  When I finally realized, probably around like 14, 15, that I was gay, but... certainly kept it to myself.  and then when i came out i came out to my family at 16 and that was sort of like okay they they acknowledged it and then we ignored it.  we ignored it for several years but here i am.

I always felt a little bit different.  I later came to realize that the reason I was feeling that way was because I wasn't really like everybody else there at all.  I wasn't lucky enough to tell my parents that I was gay.  Someone else told them.  And that was hard.  My family, it was rough for a while.  You know, we got, I got through it.
And you're stronger.
So much stronger.  Yeah.  These tears are not showing strength, but also tears aren't moving.
Your mascara isn't running.  I mean, I'm totally amazed.
Oh, thank God.

I was so worried about that.  When I was in college, that's when I first came out as far as acted on the fact that I was gay.  I hadn't really done anything before that.  Finally, one day I was taking my mother to Thanksgiving and we were listening to NPR on the radio and all of a sudden something came up about AIDS.  And my mother says to me, that's what they deserve.  And so I actually pulled off the freeway.  And you know, I told her, I said, mother, I said, is that what, and I named all of our friends, Roy and Joe and this one and that one, is that what they deserve?  I said, more importantly, is that what I deserve?  It was very difficult, but my mom and I, I realized that I needed to love her just like I wanted her to love me.  And I had to give her that unconditional love.  And so that's what I did.  And eventually she walked in the gay pride parade with us.
Isabel remembers the very first time that we met.

I remember the first time I saw her.  I was working at a restaurant.  I guess it was her first day or day of training, and she just kind of walks through the door.  I was just like, this really beautiful girl.  She's just coming up here smiling.
I remember this big-eyed girl coming up to me with all these dimples.
Look at those dimples.
You have them, too.  You get it.
How can you not?
I remember sitting across the table from her, just looking at her like, oh, no.  I think this is more than just a friend.
At this point, have you not had a relationship prior to that?

Tori's my first most things.  And she decided to say like, you know what?  I'll take you on a first date.  And I went to reach for the drink menu.  And then she goes and she reaches across and tries to, and takes my hand.  I thought she wanted, she was holding my hand.  I thought she was like, you're on a date.  I was like, oh, I'm just getting, and she was like, I am so sorry.  I think I ended up holding your hand simply out of pity after that.
Was the transition easy for you?  Living together for the first time?
Yes and no.  Who controls the remote for the TV?
Probably me.  Yeah.  More than you.
Barry controls the remote.  Okay.  Which for two men is a difficult thing.  Because in the Bible it says the man controls the remote.
It's interesting though, because I think that we have found that in this relationship, we are able to kind of set aside gender expectations that have been placed on us previously.
That's such a good point.
Okay, how did we meet?  We basically joined a bereavement group.  We both lost our spouses.  We both, through our therapist, told us to join this gay bulletin board.
I was so happy.  We went out to dinner, and his credit card worked.  And I was like, oh, that's a good one.  Let's keep this one.
So Ben and I knew, or at least I knew, that Ben and I were, he was the one early on.  How was it for you guys?
We're just best friends.
Yeah, we're best friends.
Yeah, so there's so much more than just romance that goes into having a partner.  Just just living life and doing all those things and just feeling comfortable.

I remember you were getting phone calls from family at that time.  that weren't necessarily positive ones.  You just put your phone on mute.  You put it in your pocket and you were like, they're not going to take away from tonight.  And I felt like safe and protected.  And I think that was when I first like knew it would be OK if I let myself love you.
That's so sweet, baby.
That's beautiful.
I love you.  I love that.  I love that.
No, I tell you, you got me crying, too.

So we had three wedding rings to signify three of our marriages.  So the first one was the March on Washington.  The second one was we got married up in San Francisco by Mayor Willie Brown.  He invited 180 couples from California to get married.  We were a couple 180.
It was a protest.  it was a protest marriage.
it wasn't legal and uh.  and then the third one was when we got legally married in 2008.
to me that was something we gave a gift.  by doing all those protest marriages and doing all that we've given a gift to this generation.

knocking on people's doors i mean we canvassed our neighborhoods and we'd go to our neighbors and you know and we would you know say you know us.  why are you voting against us?  why why would you do that?

i'm so grateful to you for doing those things and for being willing to step out specifically into the community and to go speak to your neighbors one by one.  And that's all that we can do to change the world around us.  What advice would you give to a young queer person who is struggling with their identity?
Reach out to your community.  There's so much support out there.  Old, young, gay, lesbian.  It's our commonality is the word community.
Yeah, don't isolate yourself.  I think that's the, when you isolate yourself, that's when your mind is open to its darkest thoughts because it gets better.
I would say let yourself be seen in whatever way that you find that is safe for you.  As soon as someone, you allow someone to see you, you see how much you matter.

For young queer people to just not listen to all the negative comments and whatever else they hear from either family, friends, people on the internet, to just try and quiet that noise and to just remember that you have worth.

Thank you for really like sharing and opening up about your life because it gave us a point of view that we were not privy to.  The commonality that I pick up from all four of us is this is something we've been waiting for all of our lives and we finally found it.  It brings tears to my eyes because it's such a such a raw emotion, you know, to have that immense love for one person on this planet.  It's just beautiful.
Well, they're going to kiss.
